{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3418304,"name":"","username":"Bookish-Girl","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bookish-girl/{size}/199348_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-27T00:51:27.957Z","cooked":"

Hello! My team and I are looking for some advice on how to build a t-shirt cannon. What materials would you guys suggest to make it able to launch comfortably into high school football stadium bleachers? Also, what should I take into account to keep the launcher safe?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-08-27T00:51:27.957Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":83,"reads":345,"readers_count":344,"score":484.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470305,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-help-please","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60319,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-help-please/470305/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3418306,"name":"Patrick McNaughton","username":"PatMcN","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patmcn/{size}/191694_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-27T00:56:39.211Z","cooked":"

While I don’t know much, I recommend you check out 254’s
https://www.team254.com/shockwave/

Most people use scuba diving tanks and charge them every few months, but we personally use 2 large tanks and have an onboard compressor. From what I’ve heard the scuba tanks are perfectly safe but still could be dangerous. Our ~70psi in our tanks shoot tshirts just fine. We use 6 large solenoids and a 7th solenoid as a barrier between our air tanks and the barrels. All the electronics are FRC parts, however I can’t recommend specific solenoids/compressor because ours are about 12 years outdated.

Edit: THIS

cbale2000:

DO NOT USE PVC

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-08-27T00:58:48.723Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":343,"readers_count":342,"score":163.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":470305,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-help-please","display_username":"Ryan Hubbs","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53872,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2152 | FIRST in FL | MoSim"},"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-help-please/470305/3","custom_user_title":"2152 | FIRST in FL | MoSim","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3418309,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-27T00:57:50.711Z","cooked":"

Some key points:

  1. DO NOT USE PVC
  2. Smaller diameter barrel = longer range, less air used, potentially harder to roll shirts
  3. Use metal sprinkler valves
  4. Flow rate is just as (if not more) important as air volume (larger diameter valve = more flow)

Our T-Shirt cannon uses a custom fabricated ~1 gallon “shot tank” in order to have large enough outlet fittings (1.5" diameter). We had this tank professionally pressure tested, well in excess of anything that would ever be put through it (we use a standard FRC regulator on the final stage and never set it above 100psi), without professional testing I would NOT recommend a custom solution.

Initially we attempted to use a high-end DC air compressor to fill the shot tank, but found it was taking 30+ seconds between each shot which was unacceptable for us. We spoke with our local fire department and got a few “renewed” (again, professionally tested and certified) 30 minute SCUBA tanks, and a main regulator that takes the pressure down from ~4000psi to about 150psi (where we then regulate it again using the smaller regulator mentioned above).

In general, we launch things between 30-80psi, and have even taken our T-shirt cannon out on the ice at our local OHL hockey rink (where we have to regulate it down so the shirts don’t end up in the rafters).

Here’s the bot: (Plus team 5216 in the background getting ready to have their FTC team to drop the puck)

Every time this topic comes up, I feel compelled to point out this paper about eye safety:

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/307577201_Risk_Assessment_of_Air_Cannons_at_Sporting_Events

T-shirt cannons are cool, and they are also GUNS that can really hurt people at close range. At my child’s school, a relatively innocuous air-powered potato gun, plus two or three process failures, resulted in a permanent eye injury.

I would suggest thinking about the safety issue as a problem of “range safety” process discipline, more than a hardware problem: who will play the role of range safety officer? what mechanisms will they use to control the state of the gun, and the behavior of the shooter? how might those mechanisms fail?

Given the risks, I personally wouldn’t bother with this particular type of project; there are plenty of fun low-risk alternative projects. But it can also be made to work, if you’re careful.

Andymark 6in pneumatic tires, moderately underinflated.
It slides but it’s controllable, similar to a lunacy robot.
To be honest the biggest control issue we have is the radio (it’s just an RC controller) that has a range of like 10ft before it starts getting really sketchy.

If SCUBA tanks aren’t readily available for you, we’ve had good luck with old fire extinguisher tanks. Ask your local fire or police department, and they’ve probably got a closet full of 'em.

On another topic

Hello Nathan,

My name is Veronica! I’m the electrical captain for FRC Team 612 and I had a couple questions about your t-shirt cannon design. Do you know how far it shot vertically and horizontally? How fast did the t-shirts shoot out?

Thank you so much! Your help is greatly appreciated.

Hey! Honestly I don’t really remember (holy crap its been 3 years) but there are some videos in this Google Drive Folder if you want to check them out. I figured I’d post in this here so others can check it out as well.
https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1cswyJ9kvBwLi16mzjixakb-xMYHxN_kL

If you haven’t already read this thread, there’s a lot of useful information in there as well (I made a few posts there as well). Feel free to send more questions here if you have any. One thing I would like to note is while I wouldn’t really change anything with the pneumatic setup, if I could go back I would design this robot very differently mechanically. It was the first robot I’ve ever designed and modeled myself and there is SO MANY improvements that could be made.

Building a T-shirt cannon robot Technical
Me and some other members of my robotics team were passed down an independent study from a former member which was a barebones concept for a T-shirt cannon robot. Containing 3 barrels that are all fed by one larger 150psi tank, many issues arose however the largest was its limited capability as far as shots fired before the tank would need to be refilled. We could maybe get off 2 shots before we would have to refill the tank. Wanting to have a working T-shirt cannon robot, some of the people on …

Here also is some screenshots from me talking to a guy from 8033 (in a public FRC server) who was also interested in a t-shirt cannon robot the other day lol
